data.text:
Kendrick Gary

Dr. Courts

BA310

November 29, 2017

HP Case Study Report

Hewlett Packard (HP) is an American multinational information technology corporation, which was founded in 1939 by Bill Hewlett and Dave Packard. HP is one of the leading companies across the globe, comprised of 150,000 employees and operates in more than 170 countries. HP provides hardware and software to Small and Medium Sized Enterprises (SMEs) as well as large corporations. HP’s purpose is to provide quality products and services to its customers, to gain customers, and to gain competitive advantage in the long run.

HP is traditionally leading in the area of business ethics, outstanding values and belief system known as HP way. HP’s way of strategy failed to achieve its goals and objectives once it became under the guidance of Carly S. Fiorina, who was Chief Executive Officer from 1999 to 2005. During her leadership, HP’s stock lost more than half of its value because of dot.com bubble boom and as a result, hurting most of the technology company.

In 2002, HP oversaw what was then the largest technology sector merger in history, when HP acquired Compaq, their rival of personal computers manufacturer. HP had to lay off 30,000 employees in order to save 80,000 jobs. The company eventually grew to 150,000 employees. In February 2005, Fiorina was forced to resign as CEO and Chair following a boardroom disagreement. HP appointed Patricia Dunn as chairman to lead the company and to help increase the
